Geography.fact: The Jordan flows south from the Sea of Galilee (Lake Kinneret).

Geography.q: Which city was destroyed alongside Sodom?
Geography.fact: Gomorrah was destroyed for wickedness, near the southeastern Dead Sea.

Geography.q: Which city housed the tabernacle for many years?
Geography.fact: The tabernacle was at Shiloh, near modern Shiloh in the central hill country.

Geography.q: Which Canaanite stronghold did Joshua destroy by fire?
Geography.fact: Hazor was burned and destroyed, at Tel Hazor in northern Israel.

Geography.q: Which city was associated with Og, king of Bashan?
Geography.fact: Edrei was one of Og's royal cities, near modern Daraa region.

Geography.q: Where did Deborah judge Israel?
Geography.fact: Deborah judged between Ramah and Bethel, near the Ramallah area.

Geography.q: Where did King Saul die?
Geography.fact: Saul died on Mount Gilboa, near Jezreel Valley in northern Israel.

Geography.q: Where did David hide from Saul?
Geography.fact: David hid in the caves of En Gedi, an oasis along the western Dead Sea.

Geography.q: Which city deceived Israel into making a treaty?
Geography.fact: The Gibeonites tricked Israel, near modern el-Jib northwest of Jerusalem.

Geography.q: Which city did Solomon fortify along with Megiddo and Hazor?
Geography.fact: Solomon fortified Gezer, at Tel Gezer west of Jerusalem.

Geography.q: Which region was home to the Philistines?
Geography.fact: The Philistines occupied the coastal plain along the Mediterranean.

Geography.q: Which mountain stood opposite Mount Gerizim?
Geography.fact: Mount Ebal was used for covenant curses, near modern Nablus.

Geography.q: Which mountain was used for covenant blessings?
Geography.fact: Blessings were proclaimed from Mount Gerizim, south of modern Nablus.

Geography.q: Which region was a desert area in southern Israel?
Geography.fact: The Negev was sparsely populated, now the Negev Desert in southern Israel.

Geography.q: Which city controlled a key mountain pass?
Geography.fact: Megiddo guarded vital trade routes, at Tel Megiddo in northern Israel.

Geography.q: Which site served as Israel's first base camp after crossing the Jordan?
Geography.fact: Israel camped at Gilgal, near the Jordan Valley east of Jericho.

Geography.q: Which city was Israel's religious center before Jerusalem?
Geography.fact: The tabernacle stood at Shiloh in the central hill country.

Geography.q: Which city was given to Caleb as an inheritance?
Geography.fact: Caleb received Hebron, south of Jerusalem.

Geography.q: Which city suffered defeat due to Achan's sin?
Geography.fact: Israel was defeated at Ai, likely near Bethel.

Geography.q: Near which city did the sun stand still?
Geography.fact: The battle occurred near Gibeon, in central Israel northwest of Jerusalem.

Geography.q: Which city was besieged by the Assyrians?
Geography.fact: Lachish was heavily attacked, at Tel Lachish in southern Israel.

Geography.q: Which city became the northern kingdom's capital?
Geography.fact: Omri built Samaria, near modern Sebastia.

Geography.q: Which city featured elders at the city gate in Ruth?
Geography.fact: Boaz met elders at Bethlehem's gate, south of Jerusalem.

Geography.q: Which region separated Judea and Galilee?
Geography.fact: Samaria lay between the two regions, in central Israel/West Bank.

Geography.q: Which region was known for balm and spices?
Geography.fact: Balm of Gilead was famous for healing, east of the Jordan River.

Geography.q: Which fortified city lay west of Jerusalem?
Geography.fact: Gezer guarded western approaches, at Tel Gezer.

Geography.q: Which city of refuge lay east of the Jordan?
Geography.fact: Bezer served as a refuge city in the eastern Jordan region.

Geography.q: Which wilderness did David flee into?
Geography.fact: David hid in the wilderness of Judah, the Judean Desert east of Jerusalem.
